proof.full:
We prove that (Olivia=Knave, Alice=Spy, Ivy=Knave) is the unique solution by showing it is consistent and all alternatives lead to contradictions.

Step 1: We first verify the proposed solution is consistent. Suppose Olivia=Knave, Alice=Spy, Ivy=Knave.

Step 2: Check Olivia's statement "Alice and I have the same role." Since Olivia=Knave and Alice=Spy, they do NOT have the same role. Olivia's statement is false. Since Olivia is a Knave (always lies), this is consistent.

Step 3: Check Alice's statement "I am a spy." Since Alice=Spy, her statement is true. Since Alice is the Spy (can lie or tell truth), speaking truth is consistent.

Step 4: Check Ivy's statement "Alice and I have the same role." Since Ivy=Knave and Alice=Spy, they do NOT have the same role. Ivy's statement is false. Since Ivy is a Knave (always lies), this is consistent.

Step 5: Check the "exactly one spy" constraint (s-005). In our assignment: Olivia=Knave, Alice=Spy, Ivy=Knave. There is exactly one Spy (Alice). This is consistent with s-005.

Step 6: The proposed solution satisfies all constraints. Therefore (Olivia=Knave, Alice=Spy, Ivy=Knave) is a valid solution.

Step 7: We now show no other solution exists by case analysis on Alice's role. By s-001, Alice is Knight, Knave, or Spy.

Step 8: Case A: Suppose Alice is a Knight (always tells truth). Alice says "I am a spy" (s-003). If Alice is a Knight, her statement must be true, so Alice is a Spy. But we assumed Alice is a Knight. Contradiction. Therefore Alice is not a Knight.

Step 9: Case B: Suppose Alice is a Knave (always lies). Alice says "I am a spy" (s-003). If Alice is a Knave, her statement must be false, so Alice is NOT a spy. This is consistent so far. Continue to check other constraints.

Step 10: Case B continued: If Alice=Knave, analyze Olivia. By s-005, there is exactly one spy, and it's not Alice. So the spy is either Olivia or Ivy.

Step 11: Case B.1: Suppose Alice=Knave and Olivia=Spy. Olivia says "Alice and I have the same role" (s-002). Since Alice=Knave and Olivia=Spy, they have different roles. So Olivia's statement is false. But Olivia is a Spy, so she can say either true or false - this alone is not a contradiction. Now check Ivy. By s-005, Ivy is not a spy, so Ivy is Knight or Knave.

Step 12: Case B.1.a: Alice=Knave, Olivia=Spy, Ivy=Knight. Ivy says "Alice and I have the same role" (s-004). Alice=Knave, Ivy=Knight, so they have different roles. Ivy's statement is false. But Ivy is a Knight (always tells truth). Contradiction.

Step 13: Case B.1.b: Alice=Knave, Olivia=Spy, Ivy=Knave. Ivy says "Alice and I have the same role" (s-004). Alice=Knave, Ivy=Knave, so they have the SAME role. Ivy's statement is true. But Ivy is a Knave (always lies). Contradiction.

Step 14: Cases B.1.a and B.1.b exhaust all possibilities for Ivy when Olivia=Spy. Both lead to contradictions. Therefore if Alice=Knave, then Olivia is not the Spy.

Step 15: Case B.2: Suppose Alice=Knave and Ivy=Spy. By s-005 and Alice=Knave, Ivy=Spy, Olivia is not the spy. So Olivia is Knight or Knave.

Step 16: Case B.2.a: Alice=Knave, Ivy=Spy, Olivia=Knight. Olivia says "Alice and I have the same role" (s-002). Alice=Knave, Olivia=Knight, so they have different roles. Olivia's statement is false. But Olivia is a Knight (always tells truth). Contradiction.

Step 17: Case B.2.b: Alice=Knave, Ivy=Spy, Olivia=Knave. Olivia says "Alice and I have the same role" (s-002). Alice=Knave, Olivia=Knave, so they have the SAME role. Olivia's statement is true. But Olivia is a Knave (always lies). Contradiction.

Step 18: Cases B.2.a and B.2.b exhaust all possibilities for Olivia when Ivy=Spy. Both lead to contradictions. Therefore if Alice=Knave, then Ivy is not the Spy.

Step 19: By Steps 14 and 18, if Alice=Knave, neither Olivia nor Ivy is the Spy. But by s-005, there is exactly one spy among the three players. Since Alice is not a spy (by Case B assumption), the spy must be Olivia or Ivy. This contradicts Steps 14 and 18. Therefore Alice is not a Knave.

Step 20: By Steps 8 and 19, Alice is neither Knight nor Knave. By s-001, Alice must be the Spy.

Step 21: Given Alice=Spy, by s-005, Olivia and Ivy are each Knight or Knave. We analyze Olivia's possibilities.

Step 22: Case C.1: Alice=Spy and Olivia=Knight. Olivia says "Alice and I have the same role" (s-002). Alice=Spy, Olivia=Knight, so they have different roles. Olivia's statement is false. But Olivia is a Knight (always tells truth). Contradiction. Therefore Olivia is not a Knight.

Step 23: By Step 22, Olivia=Knave (the only remaining option given s-001 and s-005).

Step 24: Given Alice=Spy and Olivia=Knave, analyze Ivy. By s-005, Ivy is Knight or Knave.

Step 25: Case C.2.a: Alice=Spy, Olivia=Knave, Ivy=Knight. Ivy says "Alice and I have the same role" (s-004). Alice=Spy, Ivy=Knight, so they have different roles. Ivy's statement is false. But Ivy is a Knight (always tells truth). Contradiction.

Step 26: By Step 25, Ivy is not a Knight. Therefore Ivy=Knave.

Step 27: The only consistent assignment is Alice=Spy, Olivia=Knave, Ivy=Knave. By Step 6, this assignment satisfies all constraints. By s-006, there is a unique solution. Therefore the unique solution is: Olivia=Knave, Alice=Spy, Ivy=Knave. QED.
